The **history of Egypt** has been long and rich, due to the flow of the
[Nile](/wiki/Nile "Nile") river, with its [fertile
banks](/wiki/Ancient_Egyptian_agriculture "Ancient Egyptian agriculture") and
[delta](/wiki/Nile_Delta "Nile Delta"). Its rich history also comes from its
native inhabitants and outside influence. Much of [Egypt](/wiki/Egypt
"Egypt")'s ancient history was a mystery until the secrets of ancient
[Egyptian hieroglyphs](/wiki/Egyptian_hieroglyphs "Egyptian hieroglyphs") were
deciphered with the discovery and help of the [Rosetta
Stone](/wiki/Rosetta_Stone "Rosetta Stone"). The [Great Pyramid of
Giza](/wiki/Great_Pyramid_of_Giza "Great Pyramid of Giza") is the only one of
the [Seven Wonders of the Ancient
World](/wiki/Seven_Wonders_of_the_Ancient_World "Seven Wonders of the Ancient
World") still standing. The [Lighthouse of
Alexandria](/wiki/Lighthouse_of_Alexandria "Lighthouse of Alexandria"), one of
the other Seven Wonders, is gone. The [Library of
Alexandria](/wiki/Library_of_Alexandria "Library of Alexandria") was the only
one of its kind for centuries.

Human settlement in Egypt dates back to at least 40,000 BC with
[Aterian](/wiki/Aterian "Aterian") tool manufacturing.[_[citation
needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed "Wikipedia:Citation needed")_]
[Ancient Egyptian](/wiki/Ancient_Egypt "Ancient Egypt") civilization coalesced
around 3150 BC with the political unification of [Upper and Lower
Egypt](/wiki/Upper_and_Lower_Egypt "Upper and Lower Egypt") under the first
pharaoh of the [First Dynasty](/wiki/First_Dynasty_of_Egypt "First Dynasty of
Egypt"), [Narmer](/wiki/Narmer "Narmer"). Predominately native Egyptian rule
lasted until the conquest by the [Achaemenid Empire](/wiki/Achaemenid_Empire
"Achaemenid Empire") in the sixth century BC.

In 332 BC, [Macedonian](/wiki/Macedonia_\(ancient_kingdom\) "Macedonia
\(ancient kingdom\)") ruler [Alexander the Great](/wiki/Alexander_the_Great
"Alexander the Great") conquered Egypt as he toppled the Achaemenids and
established the [Hellenistic](/wiki/Hellenistic_period "Hellenistic period")
[Ptolemaic Kingdom](/wiki/Ptolemaic_Kingdom "Ptolemaic Kingdom"), whose first
ruler was one of Alexander's former generals, [Ptolemy I
Soter](/wiki/Ptolemy_I_Soter "Ptolemy I Soter"). The Ptolemies had to fight
native rebellions and were involved in foreign and civil wars that led to the
decline of the kingdom and its final annexation by [Rome](/wiki/Ancient_Rome
"Ancient Rome"). The death of [Cleopatra](/wiki/Cleopatra "Cleopatra") ended
the nominal independence of Egypt resulting in Egypt becoming one of the
provinces of the Roman Empire.[_[citation
needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed "Wikipedia:Citation needed")_]

[Roman rule in Egypt](/wiki/Egypt_\(Roman_province\) "Egypt \(Roman
province\)") (including [Byzantine](/wiki/Byzantine_Empire "Byzantine
Empire")) lasted from 30 BC to 641 AD, with a brief interlude of control by
the [Sasanian Empire](/wiki/Sasanian_Empire "Sasanian Empire") between
619-629, known as [Sasanian Egypt](/wiki/Sasanian_Egypt "Sasanian
Egypt").[_[citation needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed
"Wikipedia:Citation needed")_] After the [Muslim conquest of
Egypt](/wiki/Muslim_conquest_of_Egypt "Muslim conquest of Egypt"), parts of
Egypt became provinces of successive [Caliphates](/wiki/Caliphate "Caliphate")
and other Muslim dynasties: [Rashidun Caliphate](/wiki/Rashidun_Caliphate
"Rashidun Caliphate") (632-661), [Umayyad Caliphate](/wiki/Umayyad_Caliphate
"Umayyad Caliphate") (661–750), [Abbasid Caliphate](/wiki/Abbasid_Caliphate
"Abbasid Caliphate") (750-909), [Fatimid Caliphate](/wiki/Fatimid_Caliphate
"Fatimid Caliphate") (909-1171), [Ayyubid Sultanate](/wiki/Ayyubid_dynasty
"Ayyubid dynasty") (1171–1260), and the [Mamluk
Sultanate](/wiki/Mamluk_Sultanate_\(Cairo\) "Mamluk Sultanate \(Cairo\)")
(1250-1517). In 1517, [Ottoman](/wiki/Ottoman_Empire "Ottoman Empire") sultan
[Selim I](/wiki/Selim_I "Selim I") captured Cairo, absorbing Egypt into the
Ottoman Empire.[_[citation needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed
"Wikipedia:Citation needed")_]

[Egypt remained entirely Ottoman](/wiki/Egypt_Eyalet "Egypt Eyalet") until
1867, except during [French
occupation](/wiki/French_campaign_in_Egypt_and_Syria "French campaign in Egypt
and Syria") from 1798 to 1801.[_[citation
needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed "Wikipedia:Citation needed")_]
Starting in 1867, Egypt became a nominally autonomous [tributary
state](/wiki/Vassal_and_tributary_states_of_the_Ottoman_Empire "Vassal and
tributary states of the Ottoman Empire") called the [Khedivate of
Egypt](/wiki/Khedivate_of_Egypt "Khedivate of Egypt"). However, Khedivate
Egypt fell under British control in 1882 following the [Anglo-Egyptian
War](/wiki/Anglo-Egyptian_War "Anglo-Egyptian War"). After the end of [World
War I](/wiki/World_War_I "World War I") and following the [Egyptian revolution
of 1919](/wiki/Egyptian_revolution_of_1919 "Egyptian revolution of 1919"), the
[Kingdom of Egypt](/wiki/Kingdom_of_Egypt "Kingdom of Egypt") was established.
While a _de jure_ independent state, the United Kingdom retained control over
foreign affairs, defense, and other matters. British occupation lasted until
1954, with the [Anglo-Egyptian agreement of
1954](/wiki/Suez_Crisis#Post_Egyptian_revolution_period "Suez Crisis").

The modern Republic of [Egypt](/wiki/Egypt "Egypt") was founded in 1953, and
with the complete withdrawal of British forces from the [Suez
Canal](/wiki/Suez_Canal "Suez Canal") in 1956, it marked the first time in
2300 years that Egypt was both fully independent and ruled by native
Egyptians.[_[citation needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed
"Wikipedia:Citation needed")_] President [Gamal Abdel
Nasser](/wiki/Gamal_Abdel_Nasser "Gamal Abdel Nasser") (president from 1956 to
1970) introduced many reforms and created the short-lived [United Arab
Republic](/wiki/United_Arab_Republic "United Arab Republic") (with
[Syria](/wiki/Syria "Syria")). His terms also saw the [Six-Day War](/wiki/Six-
Day_War "Six-Day War") and the creation of the international [Non-Aligned
Movement](/wiki/Non-Aligned_Movement "Non-Aligned Movement"). His successor,
[Anwar Sadat](/wiki/Anwar_Sadat "Anwar Sadat") (president from 1970 to 1981)
changed Egypt's trajectory, departing from many of the political, and economic
tenets of Nasserism, re-instituting a multi-party system, and launching the
[Infitah](/wiki/Infitah "Infitah") economic policy. He led Egypt in the [Yom
Kippur War](/wiki/Yom_Kippur_War "Yom Kippur War") of 1973 to regain Egypt's
Sinai Peninsula, which Israel had occupied since the Six-Day War of 1967. This
later led to the [Egypt–Israel Peace
Treaty](/wiki/Egypt%E2%80%93Israel_Peace_Treaty "Egypt–Israel Peace Treaty").

Recent Egyptian history has been dominated by events following nearly thirty
years of rule by former president [Hosni Mubarak](/wiki/Hosni_Mubarak "Hosni
Mubarak"). The [Egyptian revolution of 2011](/wiki/Egyptian_revolution_of_2011
"Egyptian revolution of 2011") deposed Mubarak and resulted in the first
democratically elected president in Egyptian history, [Mohamed
Morsi](/wiki/Mohamed_Morsi "Mohamed Morsi"). Unrest after the 2011 revolution
and related disputes led to the [2013 Egyptian coup
d'état](/wiki/2013_Egyptian_coup_d%27%C3%A9tat "2013 Egyptian coup d'état").

## Prehistory (pre–3100
BC)[[edit](/w/index.php?title=History_of_Egypt&action=edit&section=1 "Edit
section: Prehistory \(pre–3100 BC\)")]

Main articles: [Prehistoric Egypt](/wiki/Prehistoric_Egypt "Prehistoric
Egypt") and [Population history of Egypt](/wiki/Population_history_of_Egypt
"Population history of Egypt")

There is evidence of [petroglyphs](/wiki/Petroglyphs "Petroglyphs") along the
[Nile](/wiki/Nile "Nile") terraces and in desert oases. In the 10th millennium
BC, a culture of [hunter-gatherers](/wiki/Hunter-gatherer "Hunter-gatherer")
and [fishermen](/wiki/Fishing "Fishing") was replaced by a
[grain](/wiki/Cereal "Cereal")-grinding culture. Climate changes and/or
overgrazing around 6000 BC began to desiccate the pastoral lands of Egypt,
forming the [Sahara](/wiki/Sahara "Sahara"). Early tribal peoples migrated to
the Nile River, where they developed a settled agricultural
[economy](/wiki/Economic_system "Economic system") and more centralized
society.[1]

By about 6000 BC, a [Neolithic](/wiki/Neolithic "Neolithic") culture rooted in
the Nile Valley.[2] During the Neolithic era, several predynastic cultures
developed independently in [Upper and Lower Egypt](/wiki/Upper_and_Lower_Egypt
"Upper and Lower Egypt"). The [Badari culture](/wiki/Badari_culture "Badari
culture") and the successor [Naqada](/wiki/Naqada_culture "Naqada culture")
series are generally regarded as precursors to [dynastic
Egypt](/wiki/Ancient_Egypt "Ancient Egypt"). The earliest known Lower Egyptian
site, Merimda, predates the Badarian by about seven hundred years.
Contemporaneous Lower Egyptian communities coexisted with their southern
counterparts for more than two thousand years, remaining culturally distinct,
but maintaining frequent contact through trade. The earliest known evidence of
[Egyptian hieroglyphic](/wiki/Egyptian_hieroglyphs "Egyptian hieroglyphs")
inscriptions appeared during the predynastic period on Naqada III pottery
vessels, dated to about 3200 BC.[3]

## Ancient Egypt (3100–332
BC)[[edit](/w/index.php?title=History_of_Egypt&action=edit&section=2 "Edit
section: Ancient Egypt \(3100–332 BC\)")]

Main articles: [Ancient Egypt](/wiki/Ancient_Egypt "Ancient Egypt") and
[History of ancient Egypt](/wiki/History_of_ancient_Egypt "History of ancient
Egypt")

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6c/Egypt.Giza.Sphinx.02.jpg/220px-
Egypt.Giza.Sphinx.02.jpg)](/wiki/File:Egypt.Giza.Sphinx.02.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Egypt.Giza.Sphinx.02.jpg "Enlarge")

The [Great Sphinx](/wiki/Great_Sphinx_of_Giza "Great Sphinx of Giza") and the
[Pyramids of Giza](/wiki/Giza_pyramid_complex "Giza pyramid complex"), built
during the [Old Kingdom](/wiki/Old_Kingdom "Old Kingdom").

A unified kingdom was founded 3150 BC by King [Menes](/wiki/Menes "Menes"),
leading to a [series of dynasties](/wiki/List_of_Egyptian_dynasties "List of
Egyptian dynasties") that ruled Egypt for the next three millennia. [Egyptian
culture](/wiki/Culture_of_Egypt "Culture of Egypt") flourished during this
long period and remained distinctively Egyptian in its
[religion](/wiki/Ancient_Egyptian_religion "Ancient Egyptian religion"),
[arts](/wiki/Art_of_Ancient_Egypt "Art of Ancient Egypt"),
[language](/wiki/Egyptian_language "Egyptian language") and customs. The
[first two ruling dynasties](/wiki/Protodynastic_Period_of_Egypt
"Protodynastic Period of Egypt") of a unified Egypt set the stage for the [Old
Kingdom](/wiki/Old_Kingdom "Old Kingdom") period, _c_. 2700–2200 BC., which
constructed many [pyramids](/wiki/Egyptian_pyramids "Egyptian pyramids"), most
notably the [Third Dynasty](/wiki/Third_dynasty_of_Egypt "Third dynasty of
Egypt") [pyramid of Djoser](/wiki/Pyramid_of_Djoser "Pyramid of Djoser") and
the [Fourth Dynasty](/wiki/Fourth_dynasty_of_Egypt "Fourth dynasty of Egypt")
[Giza Pyramids](/wiki/Giza_pyramid_complex "Giza pyramid complex").

The [First Intermediate Period](/wiki/First_Intermediate_Period_of_Egypt
"First Intermediate Period of Egypt") ushered in a time of political upheaval
for about 150 years.[4] Stronger Nile floods and stabilization of government,
however, brought back renewed prosperity for the country in the [Middle
Kingdom](/wiki/Middle_Kingdom_of_Egypt "Middle Kingdom of Egypt") _c_. 2040
BC, reaching a peak during the reign of Pharaoh [Amenemhat
III](/wiki/Amenemhat_III "Amenemhat III"). A [second period of
disunity](/wiki/Second_Intermediate_Period_of_Egypt "Second Intermediate
Period of Egypt") heralded the arrival of the first foreign ruling dynasty in
Egypt, that of the [Semitic-speaking](/wiki/Ancient_Semitic-speaking_peoples
"Ancient Semitic-speaking peoples") [Hyksos](/wiki/Hyksos "Hyksos"). The
Hyksos invaders took over much of Lower Egypt around 1650 BC and founded a new
capital at [Avaris](/wiki/Avaris "Avaris"). They were driven out by an Upper
Egyptian force led by [Ahmose I](/wiki/Ahmose_I "Ahmose I"), who founded the
[Eighteenth Dynasty](/wiki/Eighteenth_Dynasty_of_Egypt "Eighteenth Dynasty of
Egypt") and relocated the capital from [Memphis](/wiki/Memphis,_Egypt
"Memphis, Egypt") to [Thebes](/wiki/Thebes,_Egypt "Thebes, Egypt").

The [New Kingdom](/wiki/New_Kingdom "New Kingdom"), _c_. 1550–1070 BC, began
with the Eighteenth Dynasty, marking the rise of Egypt as an [international
power](/wiki/Power_in_international_relations "Power in international
relations") that expanded during its greatest extension to an empire as far
south as [Tombos](/wiki/Tombos_\(Nubia\) "Tombos \(Nubia\)") in
[Nubia](/wiki/Nubia "Nubia"), and included parts of the [Levant](/wiki/Levant
"Levant") in the east. This period is noted for some of the most well known
[Pharaohs](/wiki/Pharaoh "Pharaoh"), including [Hatshepsut](/wiki/Hatshepsut
"Hatshepsut"), [Thutmose III](/wiki/Thutmose_III "Thutmose III"),
[Akhenaten](/wiki/Akhenaten "Akhenaten") and his wife
[Nefertiti](/wiki/Nefertiti "Nefertiti"), [Tutankhamun](/wiki/Tutankhamun
"Tutankhamun") and [Ramesses II](/wiki/Ramesses_II "Ramesses II"). The first
historically attested expression of [monotheism](/wiki/Monotheism
"Monotheism") came during this period as [Atenism](/wiki/Atenism "Atenism").
Frequent contacts with other nations brought new ideas to the New Kingdom. The
country was later invaded and conquered by [Libyans](/wiki/Ancient_Libya
"Ancient Libya"), [Nubians](/wiki/Kingdom_of_Kush "Kingdom of Kush") and
[Assyrians](/wiki/Assyria "Assyria"), but native Egyptians eventually drove
them out and regained control of their country.[5]

A team lead by [Johannes Krause](/wiki/Johannes_Krause "Johannes Krause")
managed the first reliable sequencing of the genomes of 90 mummified
individuals in 2017. Whilst not conclusive, because of the non-exhaustive time
frame and restricted location that the mummies represent, their study
nevertheless showed that these Ancient Egyptians "closely resembled ancient
and modern Near Eastern populations, especially those in the Levant, and had
almost no DNA from sub-Saharan Africa. What's more, the genetics of the
mummies remained remarkably consistent even as different powers—including
Nubians, Greeks, and Romans—conquered the empire."[6]

### Achaemenid
rule[[edit](/w/index.php?title=History_of_Egypt&action=edit&section=3 "Edit
section: Achaemenid rule")]

In the sixth century BC, the [Achaemenid Empire](/wiki/Achaemenid_Empire
"Achaemenid Empire") conquered Egypt.[_[citation
needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed "Wikipedia:Citation needed")_] The
entire [Twenty-seventh Dynasty of Egypt](/wiki/Twenty-seventh_Dynasty_of_Egypt
"Twenty-seventh Dynasty of Egypt"), from 525 BC to 402 BC, save for
[Petubastis III](/wiki/Petubastis_III "Petubastis III"), was an entirely
[Persian](/wiki/Persian_people "Persian people")-ruled period, with the
Achaemenid kings being granted the title of [pharaoh](/wiki/Pharaoh
"Pharaoh").[_[citation needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed
"Wikipedia:Citation needed")_]

The [Thirtieth Dynasty](/wiki/Thirtieth_Dynasty_of_Egypt "Thirtieth Dynasty of
Egypt") was the last native ruling dynasty during the Pharaonic
epoch.[_[citation needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed "Wikipedia:Citation
needed")_] It [fell to the Persians again](/wiki/History_of_Achaemenid_Egypt
"History of Achaemenid Egypt") in 343 BC after the last native Pharaoh, King
[Nectanebo II](/wiki/Nectanebo_II "Nectanebo II"), was defeated in
battle.[_[citation needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed "Wikipedia:Citation
needed")_]

### Second Achaemenid
conquest[[edit](/w/index.php?title=History_of_Egypt&action=edit&section=4
"Edit section: Second Achaemenid conquest")]

The [Thirty-first Dynasty of Egypt](/wiki/Thirty-first_Dynasty_of_Egypt
"Thirty-first Dynasty of Egypt"), also known as the Second Egyptian
[Satrapy](/wiki/Satrap "Satrap"), was effectively a short-living province of
the Achaemenid Empire between 343 BC to 332 BC.[_[citation
needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed "Wikipedia:Citation needed")_]

After an interval of independence, during which three indigenous dynasties
reigned (the [28th](/wiki/Twenty-eighth_Dynasty_of_Egypt "Twenty-eighth
Dynasty of Egypt"), [29th](/wiki/Twenty-ninth_Dynasty_of_Egypt "Twenty-ninth
Dynasty of Egypt") and [30th dynasty](/wiki/Thirtieth_Dynasty_of_Egypt
"Thirtieth Dynasty of Egypt")), [Artaxerxes III](/wiki/Artaxerxes_III
"Artaxerxes III") (358–338 BC) reconquered the Nile valley for a brief second
period (343–332 BC), which is called the Thirty-first Dynasty of Egypt, thus
starting another period of pharaohs of Persian origin.[_[citation
needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed "Wikipedia:Citation needed")_]

## Ptolemaic and Roman Egypt (332 BC–641
AD)[[edit](/w/index.php?title=History_of_Egypt&action=edit&section=5 "Edit
section: Ptolemaic and Roman Egypt \(332 BC–641 AD\)")]

Main articles: [Ptolemaic Kingdom](/wiki/Ptolemaic_Kingdom "Ptolemaic
Kingdom") and [Egypt (Roman province)](/wiki/Egypt_\(Roman_province\) "Egypt
\(Roman province\)")

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/49/Denderah3_Cleopatra_Cesarion.jpg/180px-
Denderah3_Cleopatra_Cesarion.jpg)](/wiki/File:Denderah3_Cleopatra_Cesarion.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Denderah3_Cleopatra_Cesarion.jpg "Enlarge")

The [Greek](/wiki/Greeks "Greeks") Ptolemaic queen [Cleopatra](/wiki/Cleopatra
"Cleopatra") and her son by [Julius Caesar](/wiki/Julius_Caesar "Julius
Caesar"), [Caesarion](/wiki/Caesarion "Caesarion"), at the [Dendera Temple
complex](/wiki/Dendera_Temple_complex "Dendera Temple complex").

The [Ptolemaic Kingdom](/wiki/Ptolemaic_Kingdom "Ptolemaic Kingdom") was a
powerful [Hellenistic state](/wiki/Hellenistic_civilization "Hellenistic
civilization") extending from southern [Syria](/wiki/Syria "Syria") in the
east, to [Cyrene](/wiki/Cyrene,_Libya "Cyrene, Libya") to the west, and south
to the frontier with Nubia. [Alexandria](/wiki/Alexandria "Alexandria") became
the capital city and a center of [Greek](/wiki/Hellenistic_Greece "Hellenistic
Greece") culture and trade. To gain recognition by the native Egyptian
populace, they named themselves as the successors to the Pharaohs. The later
Ptolemies took on Egyptian traditions, had themselves portrayed on public
monuments in Egyptian style and dress, and participated in Egyptian religious
life.[7][8]

The last ruler from the [Ptolemaic dynasty](/wiki/Ptolemaic_dynasty "Ptolemaic
dynasty") was [Cleopatra](/wiki/Cleopatra "Cleopatra"), who committed suicide
following the burial of her lover [Mark Antony](/wiki/Mark_Antony "Mark
Antony"), who had died in her arms (from a self-inflicted stab wound) after
[Augustus](/wiki/Augustus "Augustus") had captured Alexandria and her
mercenary forces had fled.

The Ptolemies faced rebellions of native Egyptians, often caused by an
unwanted regime, and were involved in foreign and civil wars that led to the
decline of the kingdom and its annexation by Rome. Nevertheless, [Hellenistic
culture](/wiki/Hellenistic_culture "Hellenistic culture") continued to thrive
in Egypt well after the [Muslim conquest](/wiki/Muslim_conquest_of_Egypt
"Muslim conquest of Egypt"). The native Egyptian/Coptic culture continued to
exist as well (the Coptic language itself was Egypt's most widely spoken
language until at least the 10th century).

Egypt quickly became the Empire's [breadbasket](/wiki/Breadbasket
"Breadbasket") supplying the greater portion of the Empire's grain in addition
to flax, papyrus, glass, and many other finished goods. The city of Alexandria
became a key trading outpost for the Roman Empire (by some accounts, the most
important for a time). Shipping from Egypt regularly reached India and
Ethiopia among other international destinations.[9] It was also a leading
(perhaps _the_ leading) scientific and technological center of the Empire.
Scholars such as [Ptolemy](/wiki/Ptolemy "Ptolemy"), [Hypatia](/wiki/Hypatia
"Hypatia"), and [Heron](/wiki/Hero_of_Alexandria "Hero of Alexandria") broke
new ground in astronomy, mathematics, and other disciplines. Culturally, the
city of Alexandria at times rivaled Rome in its importance.[10]

Christianity reached Egypt relatively early in the evangelist period of the
first century (traditionally credited to [Mark the
Evangelist](/wiki/Mark_the_Evangelist "Mark the Evangelist")).[11] Alexandria,
Egypt and Antioch, Syria quickly became the leading centers of
Christianity.[12] [Diocletian](/wiki/Diocletian "Diocletian")'s reign marked
the transition from the [Roman](/wiki/Roman_Empire "Roman Empire") to the
[Byzantine](/wiki/Byzantine_Empire "Byzantine Empire") era in Egypt, when a
great number of Egyptian Christians were persecuted. The [New
Testament](/wiki/New_Testament "New Testament") had by then been translated
into Egyptian. After the [Council of Chalcedon](/wiki/Council_of_Chalcedon
"Council of Chalcedon") in AD 451, a distinct [Egyptian Coptic
Church](/wiki/Coptic_Orthodox_Church_of_Alexandria "Coptic Orthodox Church of
Alexandria") was firmly established.[13]

### Sassanid
Egypt[[edit](/w/index.php?title=History_of_Egypt&action=edit&section=6 "Edit
section: Sassanid Egypt")]

[Sasanian Egypt](/wiki/Sasanian_Egypt "Sasanian Egypt") (known in [Middle
Persian](/wiki/Middle_Persian "Middle Persian") sources as _Agiptus_) refers
to the brief rule of Egypt and parts of [Libya](/wiki/Libya "Libya") by the
[Sasanian Empire](/wiki/Sasanian_Empire "Sasanian Empire"), which lasted from
619 to 629,[_[citation needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed
"Wikipedia:Citation needed")_] until the Sasanian rebel
[Shahrbaraz](/wiki/Shahrbaraz "Shahrbaraz") made an alliance with the
Byzantine emperor [Heraclius](/wiki/Heraclius "Heraclius") and had control
over Egypt returned to him.[_[citation needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed
"Wikipedia:Citation needed")_]

## Arab and Ottoman Egypt
(641–1882)[[edit](/w/index.php?title=History_of_Egypt&action=edit&section=7
"Edit section: Arab and Ottoman Egypt \(641–1882\)")]

Main articles: [History of Muslim Egypt](/wiki/History_of_Muslim_Egypt
"History of Muslim Egypt") and [History of Ottoman
Egypt](/wiki/History_of_Ottoman_Egypt "History of Ottoman Egypt")

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1d/Yavuz_Sultan_I._Selim_Han.jpg/150px-
Yavuz_Sultan_I._Selim_Han.jpg)](/wiki/File:Yavuz_Sultan_I._Selim_Han.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Yavuz_Sultan_I._Selim_Han.jpg "Enlarge")

[Selim I](/wiki/Selim_I "Selim I") (1470–1520), conquered Egypt

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a4/Cairo%2C_Old_Cairo%2C_Hanging_Church%2C_Egypt%2C_Oct_2004.jpg/170px-
Cairo%2C_Old_Cairo%2C_Hanging_Church%2C_Egypt%2C_Oct_2004.jpg)](/wiki/File:Cairo,_Old_Cairo,_Hanging_Church,_Egypt,_Oct_2004.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Cairo,_Old_Cairo,_Hanging_Church,_Egypt,_Oct_2004.jpg "Enlarge")

The [Hanging Church](/wiki/Hanging_Church "Hanging Church") of Cairo, first
built in the 3rd or 4th century, is one of the most famous [Coptic
Orthodox](/wiki/Coptic_Orthodox_Church_of_Alexandria "Coptic Orthodox Church
of Alexandria") churches in Egypt.

The Byzantines were able to regain control of the country after a brief
[Persian](/wiki/Aegyptus_\(Roman_province\)#Persian_and_Arab_conquests
"Aegyptus \(Roman province\)") invasion early in the 7th century, until
639–42, when Egypt was invaded and [conquered by the Arab Islamic
Empire](/wiki/Muslim_conquest_of_Egypt "Muslim conquest of Egypt"). The final
loss of Egypt was of incalculable significance to the Byzantine Empire, which
had relied on Egypt for many agricultural and manufactured goods.

When they defeated the Byzantine Armies in Egypt, the Arabs brought [Sunni
Islam](/wiki/Sunni_Islam "Sunni Islam") to the country. Early in this period,
Egyptians began to blend their new faith with their Christian traditions as
well as other indigenous beliefs and practices, leading to various
[Sufi](/wiki/Sufism "Sufism") orders that have flourished to this day.[11]
These earlier rites had survived the period of Coptic Christianity.[14]

Muslim rulers nominated by the [Islamic Caliphate](/wiki/Caliphate
"Caliphate") remained in [control of Egypt](/wiki/History_of_Arab_Egypt
"History of Arab Egypt") for the next six centuries, with [Cairo](/wiki/Cairo
"Cairo") as the seat of the Caliphate under the
[Fatimids](/wiki/Fatimid_Caliphate "Fatimid Caliphate"). With the end of the
[Kurdish](/wiki/Kurdish_people "Kurdish people") [Ayyubid
dynasty](/wiki/Ayyubid_dynasty "Ayyubid dynasty"), the [Mamluks](/wiki/Mamluk
"Mamluk"), a [Turco](/wiki/Turkic_people "Turkic
people")-[Circassian](/wiki/Circassians "Circassians") military caste, took
control about AD 1250. By the late 13th century, Egypt linked the Red Sea,
India, Malaya, and East Indies.[15] The Greek and Coptic languages and
cultures went into a steep decline in favor of Arabic culture (though Coptic
managed to last as a spoken language until the 17th century and remains a
liturgical language today). The Mamluks continued to govern the country until
the [conquest of Egypt](/wiki/History_of_Ottoman_Egypt "History of Ottoman
Egypt") by the [Ottoman Turks](/wiki/Ottoman_Turks "Ottoman Turks") in 1517,
after which it became a province of the [Ottoman Empire](/wiki/Ottoman_Empire
"Ottoman Empire"). The mid-14th-century [Black Death](/wiki/Black_Death "Black
Death") killed about 40% of the country's population.[16]

After the 15th century, the Ottoman invasion pushed the Egyptian system into
decline. The defensive militarization damaged its civil society and economic
institutions.[15] The weakening of the economic system combined with the
effects of plague left Egypt vulnerable to foreign invasion. Portuguese
traders took over their trade.[15] Egypt suffered six famines between 1687 and
1731.[17] The 1784 [famine](/wiki/Famine "Famine") cost it roughly one-sixth
of its population.[18]

The brief [French invasion of Egypt](/wiki/French_invasion_of_Egypt_\(1798\)
"French invasion of Egypt \(1798\)") led by [Napoleon
Bonaparte](/wiki/Napoleon_I_of_France "Napoleon I of France") began in 1798.
The expulsion of the French in 1801 by [Ottoman](/wiki/Ottoman_Turks "Ottoman
Turks"), [Mamluk](/wiki/Mamluk "Mamluk"), and British forces was followed by
four years of anarchy in which Ottomans, Mamluks, and
[Albanians](/wiki/Albanians "Albanians") — who were nominally in the service
of the Ottomans – wrestled for power. Out of this chaos, the commander of the
Albanian regiment, [Muhammad Ali](/wiki/Muhammad_Ali_of_Egypt "Muhammad Ali of
Egypt") ([Kavalali Mehmed Ali Pasha](/wiki/Kavalali_Mehmed_Ali_Pasha "Kavalali
Mehmed Ali Pasha")) emerged as a dominant figure and in 1805 was acknowledged
by the [Sultan](/wiki/Sultan "Sultan") in [Istanbul](/wiki/Istanbul
"Istanbul") as his [viceroy](/wiki/Viceroy "Viceroy") in Egypt; the title
implied subordination to the Sultan but this was in fact a polite fiction:
Ottoman power in Egypt was finished and Muhammad Ali, an ambitious and able
leader, established a [dynasty](/wiki/Dynasty "Dynasty") that was to rule
Egypt until the revolution of 1952. In later years, the dynasty became a
British puppet.[19]

His primary focus was military: he annexed [Northern
Sudan](/wiki/Northern_Sudan "Northern Sudan") (1820–1824), [Syria](/wiki/Syria
"Syria") (1833), and parts of [Arabia](/wiki/Arabian_Peninsula "Arabian
Peninsula") and [Anatolia](/wiki/Anatolia "Anatolia"); but in 1841 the
European powers, fearful lest he topple the Ottoman Empire itself, forced him
to return most of his conquests to the Ottomans, but he kept the Sudan and his
title to Egypt was made hereditary. A more lasting result of his military
ambition is that it required him to modernize the country. Eager to adopt the
military (and therefore industrial) techniques of the great powers, he sent
students to the West and invited training missions to Egypt. He built
industries, a system of canals for irrigation and transport, and reformed the
civil service.[19]

The introduction in 1820 of long-staple cotton, the Egyptian variety of which
became notable, transformed its agriculture into a cash-crop
[monoculture](/wiki/Monoculture "Monoculture") before the end of the century.
The social effects of this were enormous: land ownership became concentrated
and many foreigners arrived, shifting production towards international
markets.[19]

## British Protectorate
(1882–1953)[[edit](/w/index.php?title=History_of_Egypt&action=edit&section=8
"Edit section: British Protectorate \(1882–1953\)")]

Main articles: [History of Egypt under the
British](/wiki/History_of_Egypt_under_the_British "History of Egypt under the
British") and [History of modern Egypt](/wiki/History_of_modern_Egypt "History
of modern Egypt")

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/58/Cairo-
Demonstrations1919.jpg/170px-Cairo-Demonstrations1919.jpg)](/wiki/File:Cairo-
Demonstrations1919.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Cairo-Demonstrations1919.jpg "Enlarge")

Nationalists demonstrating in [Cairo](/wiki/Cairo "Cairo"), 1919

British indirect rule lasted from 1882, when the British succeeded in
defeating the Egyptian Army at [Tel el-Kebir](/wiki/Battle_of_Tel_el-Kebir
"Battle of Tel el-Kebir") in September and took control of the country, to the
[1952 Egyptian revolution](/wiki/1952_Egyptian_revolution "1952 Egyptian
revolution") which made Egypt a republic and when British advisers were
expelled.

Muhammad Ali was succeeded briefly by his son
[Ibrahim](/wiki/Ibrahim_Pasha_of_Egypt "Ibrahim Pasha of Egypt") (in September
1848), then by a grandson [Abbas I](/wiki/Abbas_I_of_Egypt "Abbas I of Egypt")
(in November 1848), then by [Said](/wiki/Sa%27id_of_Egypt "Sa'id of Egypt")
(in 1854), and [Isma'il](/wiki/Isma%27il_Pasha "Isma'il Pasha") (in 1863).
Abbas I was cautious. Said and Ismail were ambitious developers, but they
spent beyond their means. The [Suez Canal](/wiki/Suez_Canal "Suez Canal"),
built in partnership with the French, was completed in 1869. The cost of this
and other projects had two effects: it led to enormous debt to European banks,
and caused popular discontent because of the onerous taxation it required. In
1875 Ismail was forced to sell Egypt's share in the canal to the British
Government. Within three years this led to the imposition of British and
French
[controllers](/wiki/History_of_Egypt_under_the_Muhammad_Ali_dynasty#Dual_control
"History of Egypt under the Muhammad Ali dynasty") who sat in the Egyptian
cabinet, and, "with the financial power of the bondholders behind them, were
the real power in the Government."[20]

Local dissatisfaction with Ismail and with European intrusion led to the
formation of the first nationalist groupings in 1879, with [Ahmad
Urabi](/wiki/Ahmad_Urabi "Ahmad Urabi") a prominent figure. In 1882 he became
head of a nationalist-dominated ministry committed to democratic reforms
including parliamentary control of the budget. Fearing a reduction of their
control, Britain and France intervened militarily, bombarding Alexandria and
crushing the Egyptian army at the [battle of Tel el-
Kebir](/wiki/Battle_of_Tel_el-Kebir "Battle of Tel el-Kebir").[21] They
reinstalled Ismail's son [Tewfik](/wiki/Tewfik_Pasha "Tewfik Pasha") as
figurehead of a _de facto_ British protectorate.[22]

In 1914, the Protectorate was made official, and the title of the [head of
state](/wiki/Head_of_state "Head of state"), which in 1867 had changed from
_pasha_ to _[khedive](/wiki/Khedivate_of_Egypt "Khedivate of Egypt")_ , was
changed again to _[sultan](/wiki/Sultanate_of_Egypt "Sultanate of Egypt")_ ,
to repudiate the vestigial [suzerainty](/wiki/Suzerainty "Suzerainty") of the
Ottoman sultan, who was backing the [Central powers](/wiki/Central_powers
"Central powers") in the [First World War](/wiki/World_War_I "World War I").
[Abbas II](/wiki/Abbas_II_of_Egypt "Abbas II of Egypt") was deposed as khedive
and replaced by his uncle, [Hussein Kamel](/wiki/Hussein_Kamel_of_Egypt
"Hussein Kamel of Egypt"), as sultan.[23]

In 1906, the [Dinshaway Incident](/wiki/Dinshaway_Incident "Dinshaway
Incident") prompted many neutral Egyptians to join the nationalist movement.
After the First World War, [Saad Zaghlul](/wiki/Saad_Zaghlul "Saad Zaghlul")
and the [Wafd Party](/wiki/Wafd_Party "Wafd Party") led the Egyptian
nationalist movement to a majority at the local Legislative Assembly. When the
British exiled Zaghlul and his associates to [Malta](/wiki/Malta "Malta") on 8
March 1919, the country arose in its [first modern
revolution](/wiki/Egyptian_revolution_of_1919 "Egyptian revolution of 1919").
The revolt led the [UK
government](/wiki/United_Kingdom_coalition_government_\(1916%E2%80%931922\)
"United Kingdom coalition government \(1916–1922\)") to issue a [unilateral
declaration of Egypt's
independence](/wiki/Unilateral_Declaration_of_Egyptian_Independence
"Unilateral Declaration of Egyptian Independence") on 22 February 1922.[24]

The [new government](/wiki/Kingdom_of_Egypt "Kingdom of Egypt") drafted and
implemented a [constitution](/wiki/1923_Constitution_of_Egypt "1923
Constitution of Egypt") in 1923 based on a [parliamentary
system](/wiki/Parliamentary_system "Parliamentary system"). Saad Zaghlul was
popularly elected as [Prime Minister of Egypt](/wiki/Prime_Minister_of_Egypt
"Prime Minister of Egypt") in 1924. In 1936, the [Anglo-Egyptian
Treaty](/wiki/Anglo-Egyptian_Treaty_of_1936 "Anglo-Egyptian Treaty of 1936")
was concluded. Continued instability due to remaining British influence and
increasing political involvement by the king led to the dissolution of the
parliament in a military _coup d 'état_ known as the [1952
Revolution](/wiki/Egyptian_Revolution_of_1952 "Egyptian Revolution of 1952").
The [Free Officers Movement](/wiki/Free_Officers_Movement_\(Egypt\) "Free
Officers Movement \(Egypt\)") forced King [Farouk](/wiki/Farouk_of_Egypt
"Farouk of Egypt") to abdicate in support of his son
[Fuad](/wiki/Fuad_II_of_Egypt "Fuad II of Egypt").

British military presence in Egypt lasted until 1954.[25]

## Republican Egypt (since
1953)[[edit](/w/index.php?title=History_of_Egypt&action=edit&section=9 "Edit
section: Republican Egypt \(since 1953\)")]

Main articles: [History of the Republic of
Egypt](/wiki/History_of_the_Republic_of_Egypt "History of the Republic of
Egypt") and [History of modern Egypt](/wiki/History_of_modern_Egypt "History
of modern Egypt")

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f8/Begin%2C_Carter_and_Sadat_at_Camp_David_1978.jpg/220px-
Begin%2C_Carter_and_Sadat_at_Camp_David_1978.jpg)](/wiki/File:Begin,_Carter_and_Sadat_at_Camp_David_1978.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Begin,_Carter_and_Sadat_at_Camp_David_1978.jpg "Enlarge")

Celebrating the signing of the Camp David Accords: [Menachem
Begin](/wiki/Menachem_Begin "Menachem Begin"), [Jimmy
Carter](/wiki/Jimmy_Carter "Jimmy Carter"), [Anwar Al
Sadat](/wiki/Anwar_El_Sadat "Anwar El Sadat").

On 18 June 1953, the [Egyptian
Republic](/wiki/Republic_of_Egypt_\(1953%E2%80%931958\) "Republic of Egypt
\(1953–1958\)") was declared, with General [Muhammad
Naguib](/wiki/Muhammad_Naguib "Muhammad Naguib") as the first President of the
Republic. Naguib was forced to resign in 1954 by [Gamal Abdel
Nasser](/wiki/Gamal_Abdel_Nasser "Gamal Abdel Nasser") – the real architect of
the 1952 movement – and was later put under [house arrest](/wiki/House_arrest
"House arrest").

### Reign of
Nasser[[edit](/w/index.php?title=History_of_Egypt&action=edit&section=10 "Edit
section: Reign of Nasser")]

Main article: [Gamal Abdel Nasser](/wiki/Gamal_Abdel_Nasser "Gamal Abdel
Nasser")

Nasser assumed power as President in June 1956. British forces completed their
withdrawal from the occupied Suez Canal Zone on 13 June 1956. He
[nationalized](/wiki/Nationalization "Nationalization") the Suez Canal on 26
July 1956, prompting the 1956 [Suez Crisis](/wiki/Suez_Crisis "Suez Crisis").

In 1958, Egypt and Syria formed a sovereign union known as the [United Arab
Republic](/wiki/United_Arab_Republic "United Arab Republic"). The union was
short-lived, ending in 1961 when [Syria](/wiki/Syria "Syria") seceded, thus
ending the union. During most of its existence, the United Arab Republic was
also in a loose [confederation](/wiki/Confederation "Confederation") with
[North Yemen](/wiki/North_Yemen "North Yemen") (formerly the Mutawakkilite
Kingdom of Yemen) known as the [United Arab States](/wiki/United_Arab_States
"United Arab States").

In the 1967 [Six Day War](/wiki/Six_Day_War "Six Day War"), Israel invaded and
occupied Egypt's [Sinai Peninsula](/wiki/Sinai_Peninsula "Sinai Peninsula")
and the [Gaza Strip](/wiki/Gaza_Strip "Gaza Strip"), which Egypt had occupied
since the [1948 Arab–Israeli War](/wiki/1948_Arab%E2%80%93Israeli_War "1948
Arab–Israeli War"). Three years later (1970), President Nasser died and was
succeeded by [Anwar Sadat](/wiki/Anwar_Sadat "Anwar Sadat").

### Reign of
Sadat[[edit](/w/index.php?title=History_of_Egypt&action=edit&section=11 "Edit
section: Reign of Sadat")]

Main article: [Anwar el-Sadat](/wiki/Anwar_el-Sadat "Anwar el-Sadat")

Sadat switched Egypt's [Cold War](/wiki/Cold_War "Cold War") allegiance from
the Soviet Union to the United States, expelling Soviet advisors in 1972. He
launched the [Infitah](/wiki/Infitah "Infitah") economic reform policy, while
clamping down on religious and secular opposition.

In 1973, Egypt, along with Syria, launched the [October
War](/wiki/Yom_Kippur_War "Yom Kippur War"), a surprise attack against the
Israeli forces occupying the Sinai Peninsula and the [Golan
Heights](/wiki/Golan_Heights "Golan Heights"). It was an attempt to regain
part of the Sinai territory that Israel had captured six years earlier. Sadat
hoped to seize some territory through military force, and then regain the rest
of the peninsula by diplomacy. The conflict sparked an international crisis
between the US and the USSR, both of whom intervened. The second UN-mandated
ceasefire halted military action. While the war ended with a military
stalemate, it presented Sadat with a political victory that later allowed him
to regain the Sinai in return for peace with Israel.[26]

Sadat made a historic visit to Israel in 1977, which led to the 1979 [peace
treaty](/wiki/Israel-Egypt_Peace_Treaty "Israel-Egypt Peace Treaty") in
exchange for Israeli withdrawal from Sinai. Sadat's initiative sparked
enormous controversy in the [Arab world](/wiki/Arab_world "Arab world") and
led to Egypt's expulsion from the [Arab League](/wiki/Arab_League "Arab
League"), but it was supported by most
Egyptians.[27][_[dubious](/wiki/Wikipedia:Accuracy_dispute#Disputed_statement
"Wikipedia:Accuracy dispute") – [discuss](/wiki/Talk:History_of_Egypt#Dubious
"Talk:History of Egypt")_] On 6 October 1981, [Sadat and six diplomats were
assassinated](/wiki/Assassination_of_Anwar_El_Sadat "Assassination of Anwar El
Sadat") while observing a military parade commemorating the eighth anniversary
of the October 1973 War. He was succeeded by [Hosni
Mubarak](/wiki/Hosni_Mubarak "Hosni Mubarak").

### Terrorist
insurgency[[edit](/w/index.php?title=History_of_Egypt&action=edit&section=13
"Edit section: Terrorist insurgency")]

Main article: [Terrorism in Egypt](/wiki/Terrorism_in_Egypt "Terrorism in
Egypt")

In 1980s, 1990s, and 2000s, terrorist attacks in Egypt became numerous and
severe, and began to target [Copts](/wiki/Copts "Copts") and foreign tourists
as well as government officials.[28] Some scholars and authors have credited
Islamist writer [Sayyid Qutb](/wiki/Sayyid_Qutb "Sayyid Qutb"), who was
executed in 1967, as the inspiration for the new wave of attacks.[29][30]

The 1990s saw an [Islamist group](/wiki/Islamism "Islamism"), [al-Gama'a al-
Islamiyya](/wiki/Al-Gama%27a_al-Islamiyya "Al-Gama'a al-Islamiyya"), engage in
an extended campaign of violence, from the murders and attempted murders of
prominent writers and intellectuals, to the repeated targeting of tourists and
foreigners. Serious damage was done to the largest sector of Egypt's
economy—tourism[31]—and in turn to the government, but it also devastated the
livelihoods of many of the people on whom the group depended for support.[32]

Victims of the campaign against the Egyptian state from 1992-1997 exceeded
1,200[33] and included the head of the counter-terrorism police (Major General
Raouf Khayrat), a speaker of parliament ([Rifaat el-Mahgoub](/wiki/Rifaat_el-
Mahgoub "Rifaat el-Mahgoub")), dozens of European tourists and Egyptian
bystanders, and over 100 Egyptian police.[34]

At times, travel by foreigners in parts of [Upper Egypt](/wiki/Upper_Egypt
"Upper Egypt") was severely restricted and dangerous.[35]

On 17 November 1997, [62 people, mostly tourists, were
killed](/wiki/Luxor_massacre "Luxor massacre") near [Luxor](/wiki/Luxor
"Luxor"). The assailants trapped the people in the [Mortuary Temple of
Hatshepsut](/wiki/Mortuary_Temple_of_Hatshepsut "Mortuary Temple of
Hatshepsut").

During this period, Al-Gama'a al-Islamiyya was given support by the
governments of Iran and Sudan, as well as [al-Qaeda](/wiki/Al-Qaeda "Al-
Qaeda").[36] The Egyptian government received support during that time from
the United States.[36]

### Civil unrest since
2011[[edit](/w/index.php?title=History_of_Egypt&action=edit&section=14 "Edit
section: Civil unrest since 2011")]

Main article: [Egyptian crisis
(2011–14)](/wiki/Egyptian_crisis_\(2011%E2%80%9314\) "Egyptian crisis
\(2011–14\)")

####
Revolution[[edit](/w/index.php?title=History_of_Egypt&action=edit&section=15
"Edit section: Revolution")]

Main article: [Egyptian revolution of 2011](/wiki/Egyptian_revolution_of_2011
"Egyptian revolution of 2011")

In 2003, the _[Kefaya](/wiki/Kefaya "Kefaya")_ ("Egyptian Movement for
Change"), was launched to oppose the Mubarak regime and to establish
democratic reforms and greater [civil liberties](/wiki/Civil_liberties "Civil
liberties").

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f3/Tahrir_Square_on_February11.png/220px-
Tahrir_Square_on_February11.png)](/wiki/File:Tahrir_Square_on_February11.png)

[](/wiki/File:Tahrir_Square_on_February11.png "Enlarge")

Celebrations in [Tahrir Square](/wiki/Tahrir_Square "Tahrir Square") after
[Omar Suleiman](/wiki/Omar_Suleiman "Omar Suleiman")'s statement announcing
[Hosni Mubarak](/wiki/Hosni_Mubarak "Hosni Mubarak")'s resignation

On 25 January 2011, widespread protests began against Mubarak's government.
The objective of the protest was the removal of Mubarak from power. These took
the form of an intensive campaign of [civil resistance](/wiki/Civil_resistance
"Civil resistance") supported by a very large number of people and mainly
consisting of continuous mass demonstrations. By 29 January, it was becoming
clear that Mubarak's government had lost control when a curfew order was
ignored, and the army took a semi-neutral stance on enforcing the curfew
decree. Some protesters, a very small minority in Cairo, expressed views
against what they deemed was foreign interference, highlighted by the then-
held view that the U.S. administration had failed to take
sides[_[clarification needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Please_clarify "Wikipedia:Please
clarify")_], as well as linking the administration with Israel.[37]

On 11 February 2011, Mubarak resigned and fled Cairo. Vice President [Omar
Suleiman](/wiki/Omar_Suleiman "Omar Suleiman") announced that Mubarak had
stepped down and that the [Egyptian military](/wiki/Egyptian_military
"Egyptian military") would assume control of the nation's affairs in the short
term.[38][39] Jubilant celebrations broke out in [Tahrir
Square](/wiki/Tahrir_Square "Tahrir Square") at the news.[40] Mubarak may have
left Cairo for [Sharm el-Sheikh](/wiki/Sharm_el-Sheikh "Sharm el-Sheikh") the
previous night, before or shortly after the airing of a taped speech in which
Mubarak vowed he would not step down or leave.[41]

On 13 February 2011, the high level military command of Egypt announced that
both the constitution and the parliament of Egypt had been dissolved. The
parliamentary election was to be held in September.[42]

A [constitutional referendum](/wiki/Egyptian_constitutional_referendum,_2011
"Egyptian constitutional referendum, 2011") was held on 19 March 2011. On 28
November 2011, Egypt held its [first parliamentary
election](/wiki/Egyptian_parliamentary_election,_2011%E2%80%932012 "Egyptian
parliamentary election, 2011–2012") since the previous regime had been in
power. Turnout was high and there were no reports of violence, although
members of some parties broke the ban on campaigning at polling places by
handing out pamphlets and banners.[43] There were however complaints of
irregularities.[44]

#### Morsi's
presidency[[edit](/w/index.php?title=History_of_Egypt&action=edit&section=16
"Edit section: Morsi's presidency")]

Main article: [Timeline of the Egyptian Crisis under Mohamed
Morsi](/wiki/Timeline_of_the_Egyptian_Crisis_under_Mohamed_Morsi "Timeline of
the Egyptian Crisis under Mohamed Morsi")

[The first round of a presidential election was held in Egypt on 23 and 24 May
2012](/wiki/Egyptian_presidential_election,_2012 "Egyptian presidential
election, 2012"). [Mohamed Morsi](/wiki/Mohamed_Morsi "Mohamed Morsi") won 25%
of the vote and [Ahmed Shafik](/wiki/Ahmed_Shafik "Ahmed Shafik"), the last
prime minister under deposed leader Hosni Mubarak, 24%. A second round was
held on 16 and 17 June. On 24 June 2012, the election commission announced
that Mohamed Morsi had won the election, making him the first democratically
elected president of Egypt. According to official results, Morsi took 51.7
percent of the vote while Shafik received 48.3 percent.

On 8 July 2012, Egypt's new president [Mohamed Morsi](/wiki/Mohamed_Morsi
"Mohamed Morsi") announced he was overriding the military [edict](/wiki/Edict
"Edict") that dissolved the country's elected parliament and he called
lawmakers back into session.[45]

On 10 July 2012, the [Supreme Constitutional Court of
Egypt](/wiki/Supreme_Constitutional_Court_of_Egypt "Supreme Constitutional
Court of Egypt") negated the decision by Morsi to call the nation's parliament
back into session.[46] On 2 August 2012, Egypt's Prime Minister Hisham Qandil
announced his 35-member cabinet comprising 28 newcomers including four from
the influential [Muslim Brotherhood](/wiki/Muslim_Brotherhood "Muslim
Brotherhood"), six others and the former military ruler [Mohamed Hussein
Tantawi](/wiki/Mohamed_Hussein_Tantawi "Mohamed Hussein Tantawi") as the
Defence Minister from the previous Government.[47]

On 22 November 2012, Morsi issued a declaration immunizing his decrees from
challenge and seeking to protect the work of the constituent assembly drafting
the new constitution.[48] The declaration also requires a retrial of those
accused in the Mubarak-era killings of protesters, who had been acquitted, and
extends the mandate of the constituent assembly by two months. Additionally,
the declaration authorizes Morsi to take any measures necessary to protect the
revolution. Liberal and secular groups previously walked out of the
constitutional constituent assembly because they believed that it would impose
strict Islamic practices, while [Muslim Brotherhood](/wiki/Muslim_Brotherhood
"Muslim Brotherhood") backers threw their support behind Morsi.[49]

The move was criticized by [Mohamed ElBaradei](/wiki/Mohamed_ElBaradei
"Mohamed ElBaradei"), the leader of Egypt's Constitution Party, who stated
"Morsi today usurped all state powers & appointed himself Egypt's new pharaoh"
on his Twitter feed.[50][51] The move led to massive protests and violent
action throughout Egypt.[52] On 5 December 2012, Tens of thousands of
supporters and opponents of Egypt's president clashed, hurling rocks and
Molotov cocktails and brawling in Cairo's streets, in what was described as
the largest violent battle between Islamists and their foes since the
country's revolution.[53] Six senior advisors and three other officials
resigned from the government and the country's leading Islamic institution
called on Morsi to stem his powers. Protesters also clamored from coastal
cities to desert towns.[54]

Morsi offered a "national dialogue" with opposition leaders but refused to
cancel a 15 December vote on a draft constitution written by an Islamist-
dominated assembly that has ignited two weeks of political unrest.[54]

[A constitutional referendum](/wiki/Egyptian_constitutional_referendum,_2012
"Egyptian constitutional referendum, 2012") was held in two rounds on 15 and
22 December 2012, with 64% support, and 33% against. It was signed into law by
a presidential decree issued by Morsi on 26 December 2012. On 3 July 2013, the
constitution was suspended by order of the Egyptian army.

On 30 June 2013, on the first anniversary of the election of Morsi, millions
of protesters across Egypt took to the streets and demanded the immediate
resignation of the president. On 1 July, the Egyptian Armed Forces issued a
48-hour ultimatum that gave the country's political parties until 3 July to
meet the demands of the Egyptian people. The presidency rejected the Egyptian
Army's 48-hour ultimatum, vowing that the president would pursue his own plans
for national reconciliation to resolve the political crisis. On 3 July,
General [Abdel Fattah el-Sisi](/wiki/Abdel_Fattah_el-Sisi "Abdel Fattah el-
Sisi"), head of the Egyptian Armed Forces, announced that he had removed Morsi
from power, suspended the constitution and would be calling new presidential
and Shura Council elections and named [Supreme Constitutional
Court](/wiki/Supreme_Constitutional_Court_of_Egypt "Supreme Constitutional
Court of Egypt")'s leader, [Adly Mansour](/wiki/Adly_Mansour "Adly Mansour")
as acting president. Mansour was sworn in on 4 July 2013.

#### After
Morsi[[edit](/w/index.php?title=History_of_Egypt&action=edit&section=17 "Edit
section: After Morsi")]

Main article: [Post-coup unrest in Egypt (2013–2014)](/wiki/Post-
coup_unrest_in_Egypt_\(2013%E2%80%932014\) "Post-coup unrest in Egypt
\(2013–2014\)")

[![\[icon\]](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1c/Wiki_letter_w_cropped.svg/20px-Wiki_letter_w_cropped.svg.png)](/wiki/File:Wiki_letter_w_cropped.svg) |  **This section needs expansion**. You can help by [adding to it](//en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=History_of_Egypt&action=edit&section=). _(March 2014)_  
---|---  
  
During the months after the [coup
d'état](/wiki/2013_Egyptian_coup_d%27%C3%A9tat "2013 Egyptian coup d'état"), a
[new constitution](/wiki/Constitution_of_Egypt "Constitution of Egypt") was
prepared, which took effect on 18 January 2014. After that,
[presidential](/wiki/Egyptian_presidential_election,_2014 "Egyptian
presidential election, 2014") and
[parliamentary](/wiki/Egyptian_parliamentary_election,_2015 "Egyptian
parliamentary election, 2015") elections have to be held in June 2014.

On 24 March 2014, 529 Morsi's supporters were [sentenced to
death](/wiki/Death_sentence "Death sentence"), while the [trial of
Morsi](/wiki/Mohamed_Morsi#Trial "Mohamed Morsi") himself was still
ongoing.[55] Having delivered a final judgement, 492 sentences were commuted
to life imprisonment with "only" 37 death sentences being upheld.

On 28 April, another mass trial took place with 683 Morsi supporters sentenced
to death for killing 1 police officer.[56]

In 2015, Egypt participated in the [Saudi Arabian-led intervention in
Yemen](/wiki/Saudi_Arabian-led_intervention_in_Yemen "Saudi Arabian-led
intervention in Yemen").[57]

el-Sisi")

In the elections of June 2014 El-Sisi won with a percentage of 96.1.

Under President el-Sisi, Egypt has implemented a rigorous policy of
controlling the border to the Gaza Strip, including the dismantling of tunnels
between the Gaza strip and Sinai.
